MacBook Air 2018 Keyboard Interface

An interface many of us use every day, the keyboard is an input device for personal computers and laptops.
It allows users to type digital characters into a computer system to write words and invoke commands,
for the purposes of editing documents, searching the internet, and more.

Figure 1. MacBook Air 2018 Keyboard Layout (Top View)

Figure 2. MacBook Air 2018 Keyboard Layout (Top View)

Interview Process

I observed and interviewed three individuals using this keyboard to learn about their experience using it. I principally wanted to focus on three areas:

  • Comfort of use
  • Recognizability of layout
  • Familiarity with shortcut commands

For the first metric, I primarily paid attention to how the users sat, and how they positioned their arms and hands while typing. For the second and third, I observed their behaviour following prompts and exercises. The observation period consisted of three steps:

  1. Perform an online typing test
  2. Copying and pasting text
  3. Holding down each of 
    fn
    , 
    control
    , 
    option
    , and 
    command
    keys, and pressing different regular characters

Observations

User 1: User appeared to be accustomed to layout of character keys, and did not need to look at the keyboard when typing in the online test. 73 WPM. User attempted to copy and paste with the control key, instead of the command key.
User 2: User was comfortable with the Mac keyboard, but frequently looked down at the keys during the typing test. 40 WPM. User correctly used command key to copy and paste on first attempt. Appeared to be caught off-guard by some of the more obscure functions, like 
option+h
.
User 3: User performed typing test with relative ease. 75 WPM. User had good working knowledge of different commands, for instance: the difference between 
command+w
and 
command+q
. Position of arms looked unnatural/uncomfortable.

Interview Questions

  1. Did you find this keyboard to be comfortable to type on?
  2. How does the feeling of pressing keys compare to keyboards you're used to?
  3. Is the compressed keyboard layout comfortable for your hands?
  4. Do you find yourself wishing that any of the keys were larger, smaller, or placed in different locations?
  5. Is the copy + paste motion comfortable? What fingers do you use to accomplish this task?
  6. Do you regularly use MacBook keyboards? If not, do you use other keyboards, and what system are they for?
  7. Do you find that the modifier keys have consistent behaviors and functions?
  8. What commands were you already familiar with?

Summary

  • Users who primarily use Windows found the copying and pasting control to be awkward, and the commands unintuitive and poorly grouped.
  • Users who primarily use Mac were comfortable with copying and pasting, but were surprised by some of the command functions.
  • Overall, the keyboard was thought to be comfortable to type on, but some may have preferred the keys to have a bit more travel.
  • Users agreed that there were too many modifier keys (`fn`, `control`, `option`, and `command`) with obscure functionality.

Personas

Using the information garnered by the interview and observation process, I aggregated users' experiences into two personas, roughly representing the main user groups of this product.

Figure 3. Ivan writes code on Windows/Linux keyboard layouts, and dislikes unnecessary complications.

Figure 4. Carly studies language arts at university, and is getting used to a MacBook as a first computer.

Storyboard

Thanks for visiting my project! I hope you enjoyed exploring an everyday interface with a bit more granularity than usual.
